events.name: Entering the Danger Zone
5,800m - Entering the Danger Zone
events.about:
Chimborazo's upper elevations are covered in glaciers that are decreasing in size due to climate change and falling ash from the nearby volcano, Tungurahua. In addition to the glaciers, the volcano is covered with craters. In 1802, scientist and explorer Baron Alexander von Humboldt, Aimé Bonpland and Carlos Montúfar attempted to reach the summit. They reached “an insurmountable cleft” at 5,875 m, higher than previously attained by any European in history.

It is 5,699m on November 10, 1993 that three parties of climbers, one ascending and two descending, were caught in an avalanche. It buried ten climbers in a crevasse.

assets.name: Humbodlt’s Expedition
assets.about:
Alexander von Humboldt (1769 -1859) was a Prussian geographer, naturalist and explorer. His work on botanical geography laid the foundation for the field of biogeography.

Between 1799 and 1804, Humboldt travelled extensively in Latin America, exploring and describing it for the first time from a modern scientific point of view. His description of the journey was written up and published in an enormous set of volumes over 21 years.

Until the beginning of the 19th century, it was thought that Chimborazo was the highest mountain on Earth (measured from sea level), and such reputation led to many attempts on its summit during the 17th and 18th centuries. In 1802, Humboldt, Bonpland and Montúfar had the summit in sight when blood vessels in their eyes burst and a crevasse forced his party to retreat.

Following the postponement of French Captain Baudin's proposed voyage of circumnavigation of the globe in 1798, Humboldt left Paris for Marseille with Aimé Bonpland, hoping to join Napoleon Bonaparte in Egypt.

The two travellers found their way to Madrid, where patron Don Mariano Luis de Urquijo convinced them to explore Spanish America.

After travelling to Tenerife and Cuba and exploring the Orinoco River in New Granada (present day Venezuela) they crossed the Cordillera Real to reach Quito. They made an ascent of Pichincha and the attempt on Chimborazo, a world record at the time. The journey concluded with an expedition to the sources of the Amazon en route for Lima, Peru.

On November 10, 1993 three parties of climbers, one ascending and two descending, were caught in an avalanche on the steep slopes below the Veintimilla summit. This avalanche buried ten climbers – six French, two Ecuadorans, one Swiss, and one Chilean in a crevasse at 5,699m.

After the ten climbers were buried in snow, it took twenty people and ten days to find their bodies. This is considered the worst climbing accident in Ecuador to date.

assets.name: Andean Condor
assets.about:
The national symbol of Ecuador, the Andean condor (Vultur gryphus) is a South American bird in the New World vulture family Cathartidae. It has a maximum wingspan of 3.2 m and plays an important role in the folklore and mythology of the Andean regions.

The condor is primarily a scavenger, feeding on carrion. It prefers large carcasses, such as those of deer or cattle. It nests at elevations of up to 5,000 m generally on inaccessible rock ledges.

It is one of the world's longest-living birds, with a lifespan of over 70 years. The Andean condor is considered near threatened by the IUCN.

assets.name: Chimborazo – A ticking bomb
assets.about:
The image shows the crater on nearby Cotapaxi. Despite its benign appearance Chimborazo is still a potentially hazardous volcano due to its height, history of explosive eruptions, and closeness to populated areas in Ambato and Riobamba basins.

At least seven eruptions took place from 8000 years to 1400 years ago producing pyroclastic flow, surge and lapilli fall deposits. The average time interval between eruptions is about 1000 years, and the last eruption was about 1400 years ago.

Although Chimborazo is officially considered inactive, studies show that there might be an eruption in the future. The last eruption was 1400 years ago, so statistically Chimborazo should still be viewed as dangerous.

assets.name: Chimborazo Glaciers
assets.about: The top of Chimborazo is completely covered by glaciers, with some north-eastern glacier arms flowing down to 4,600 m. Its glacier is the source of water for the population of the Bolivar and Chimborazo provinces of Ecuador. Chimborazo glacier's ice mass has decreased over the past decades, which is thought by some to be due to the combined influences of global warming, ash covers from recent volcanic activity of Tungurahua, and the El Niño phenomenon. As on other glaciated Ecuadorian mountains, Chimborazo's glacial ice has been mined for centuries by locals. These people are the so-called Hieleros from Spanish Hielo for “ice”). It is sold in the markets of Guaranda and Riobamba. In earlier days, the people transported ice for cooling uses down to coastal towns such as Babahoyo or Vinces.
